segments.text: cards on Saturday night, and they prided themselves on eating my son a cake on Saturday.
Of course butter was so hard to gather, but my mother had given me a recipe for an eggless, butterless, milkless cake.
And the Chinaman's cook told the boys out at the hotel that he couldn't make cake because he didn't have any butter or eggs.
And they said, well, senor makes a cake with no butter and no eggs.
And the Chinaman said, what is that?
And the boys said it over again to him.
He said, es mentira.
eggless, butterless, and milkless cake that you made during the war, or like fruit cake.
But they always called it my Mantera cake.
We had, I guess, a crew about, I guess, an office.
He had an assistant superintendent and an assayer and engineer, five or six men who were all either Americans or English.
And then they
I think they had men in the right over the miners who thought it was a Mexican foreman.
So they thought they were operating it really under Mexican control, because they didn't have a Mexican foreman.
Did any of the other engineers bring their wives at a later time?
Well, you see, this was sort of an unsettled time down there.

There was one other couple, and then an engineer and his wife, he was a Purdue University man, and his wife came down to install a power plant down at the railroad station, and they stayed with us for six or eight months.
And I think there was one other couple at one time, but they sort of came and went.
They were only there for a short period.
They were...
It was a...
an interesting life, but I'm sorry I don't have more of the details.
Mine is sort of a rambling.
It's been a very interesting story, and you've had a lot of interesting details.
I certainly do appreciate it.
It's been a pleasure talking with you.

name and uh when you were born and and just i forgot to ask you well that's that's rather personal oh well you don't have to say when you were born just no i don't mind i was born in i was born in salem indiana and my maiden name was jones kemp k-e-m-p camp and and i um that was in december 12 1887. wait a minute
Yes, 1887, so I'm 85.
And then when I was in college, my family moved to California, so I was married in California.
I married a man from Michigan who was living in California at the time.
And then after he graduated from Stanford, of course, he went to the mining business and carried me down there.
Did he ever have any occasion to talk about or to know Hoover?
Yes, he had very, he always said that his middle name was Hoover.
He, when Mr. Adams was a, in college, Mr. Hoover, Mr. and Ms. Hoover came there to address the geology club with which Mr. Adams was president.
So he met them personally and she'll pick them over then.
them over the campus and all.
Always a very sweet recollection of his visit with the Hoovers.
And then when, later, when we went to New York and Mr. Hoover was living at the Waldorf, the Strattons called on him.
And that was one of the highlights of his life.
Mr. Hoover never forgot old acquaintances.
Of course, he knew all the old Stanford props and all, so he had a great deal to talk over.
Nowadays tape recorders work fine.
Yeah, one of the great values is, from the standpoint of linguistics and, of course, the recording of the story as it's told by the person involved.
